channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israel Says It Killed Hezbollah Commander in Airstrike Near Beirut
item.description: The strike was in retaliation for a deadly rocket attack this weekend in the Golan Heights. At least three civilians were killed and 74 others wounded on Tuesday, Lebanese officials said.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Adam Rasgon, Euan Ward, Farnaz Fassihi and Hwaida Saad
item.media:credit: Hussein Malla/Associated Press
item.media:description: A destroyed building in the southern suburbs of Beirut, Lebanon, after an Israeli strike on Tuesday. At least one person was killed.

item.title: Bonsucro Certified Indian Sugar From Abusive Fields
item.description: Much of what consumers buy is marked “sustainable,” “humane” or “green.” In the sugar cane fields of India, that papered over the worst abuses.
item.dc:creator: Megha Rajagopalan
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Dalmia Bharat Sugar and Industries Ltd
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Dalmia Bharat Sugar factory in Kolhapur, India, in 2023. A New York Times investigation found that inspections by a group that certifies the mill were all but guaranteed not to find problems.

item.title: Olympic Surfing Comes to a ‘Poisoned’ Paradise
item.description: In 1974, a radioactive cloud from a French nuclear test drifted over Teahupo’o, Tahiti, now the surfing venue for the Paris Games. Villagers still feel the effects.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech and Adam Ferguson

item.title: Southport Mourns 3 Stabbing Victims: ‘Just Little Girls Who Wanted to Dance’
item.description: A day after a knife attack that killed three children, the community of Southport was grappling with the violence that had visited the town.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Adam Vaughan/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Leaving tributes on Tuesday at the scene of a stabbing attack in Southport, England. Three children died from their injuries.

item.title: After Biden’s Withdrawal, Some Want Their Aged Leaders to Follow His Lead
item.description: Most of the world’s oldest leaders — in their 80s and even one in his 90s — are in Africa, which happens to have the youngest population of any continent.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Paul Biya of Cameroon with his wife, Chantal Biya, in Yaoundé, the capital, in May. At 91, Mr. Biya is the world’s oldest leader.

item.title: How Did Venezuela Get Here?
item.description: A movement started by Hugo Chávez, promising power to the people, became an authoritarian regime, one that opponents say just stole an election.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The likenesses of Hugo Chávez, Simón Bolivar and Nicolás Maduro on a mural near a polling station during the Presidential election in Petare, Venezuela, on Sunday.

item.title: As U.S.-Iran Conflict Builds, Iraq Is Caught in Middle
item.description: The United States and Iran are at odds over the Gaza war as well as proposals for an American troop withdrawal from Iraq.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Popular Mobilization Forces, a mostly Shiite militia group, at their post at the Iraqi border with Syria in 2017.

item.title: Southport Stabbing: What We Know About the Knife Attack and Suspect
item.description: A third child has died and five more are in critical condition after a “ferocious” attack at a Taylor Swift-themed dance class on Monday. Ms. Swift expressed her horror and shock at the incident.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: James Speakman/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Police officers securing the area after a knife attack that killed three children in Southport, England, on Monday.

item.title: Russia Seizes Urozhaine and Staromaiorske From Ukraine After Furious Battles
item.description: “It was like a fight between two packs of dogs,” said an officer, describing the struggle for one of the areas, Urozhaine. But “there came a moment when it made no sense to keep people there.”
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall, Kamila Hrabchuk and David Guttenfelder
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times

item.title: France Backs Morocco’s Western Sahara Plan in Letter to King
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron said Paris would support Morocco’s plan, which gives the disputed territory limited autonomy but keeps it under Moroccan control.
item.dc:creator: Aida Alami and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Christophe Ena/Associated Press
item.media:description: Protesters with the Moroccan flag in Paris in 2016. France had previously argued that Morocco’s plan for autonomy for Western Sahara was a “serious and credible” basis for discussion, but not the only one.

item.title: Bangladesh Dragnet Sweeps Up Thousands in Protest Crackdown
item.description: Charges include vandalism, arson, theft, trespassing and damage to state property. A rights group called it a witch hunt, following an initial crackdown during which more than 200 people were killed.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Saif Hasnat
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Monirul Alam/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A suspect arrested in connection with the violence during student protests being escorted to the Chief Metropolitan Magistrate Court in Dhaka this week.

item.title: Venezuelan Political Leaders Call for Rallies Over Contested Election Results
item.description: The fatal violence comes as both President Nicolás Maduro and the opposition claimed victory in the presidential election. More protests were taking place on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles and Isayen Herrera
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Friends of Anthony Garcia, 20, at his grave in Caracas on Tuesday. Mr. Garcia was shot and killed on Monday while driving near a protest in El Valle, a working-class neighborhood in the capital.

item.title: Ukraine Ramps Up Mobilization of Troops
item.description: Large numbers of recruits will arrive at the front in the coming weeks, soldiers and military analysts said, but some are poorly trained or out of shape.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Training in June. Personnel shortages have been one of Ukraine’s biggest problems on the battlefield for the past year.

item.title: Landslides Hit Kerala in India, Killing More Than 100 People
item.description: Rescue workers struggled to reach isolated villages in the state of Kerala, where torrential rains have washed away terrain. The death toll was expected to rise.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir and Anupreeta Das
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.media:description: Rescuers carried a body in Wayanad, a district in Kerala State in southern India, on Tuesday.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: The killing of a top Hamas leader in Iran.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Arif Hudaverdi Yaman/Anadolu, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Ismail Haniyeh led Hamas’s political operations from exile in Qatar.

item.title: Traveling to China? Here’s What to Know.
item.description: China has been rolling out new visa-free programs and promising to make travel easier for foreigners. But challenges remain.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Vincent Thian/Associated Press
item.media:description: Tourists near Shichahai Lake in Beijing this month. China has been taking unusual steps to attract visitors from overseas.

item.title: Why Chinese Propaganda Loves Foreign Travel Influencers
item.description: Videos by influencers documenting their trips have been widely promoted on Chinese media — if they tell a certain story.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang

item.title: War Gives Palestinian Olympians a New Role: Athlete-Diplomats
item.description: The Israel-Hamas war has given the eight Palestinians competing in Paris Olympics a higher profile than usual.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Palestinian boxer Wasim Abusal competed with a flag on his top.

item.title: What We Know About Ismail Haniyeh.
item.description: He was central to the group’s high-stakes negotiations and diplomacy.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Majid Asgaripour/Wana News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: Ismail Haniyeh, a top Hamas leader, in Tehran in March.

item.title: Olympic Triathlons to Go Ahead After Seine Pollution Worries
item.description: The races were scheduled for Wednesday morning. The men’s event was postponed on Tuesday after tests showed the river was not safe for swimming.
item.dc:creator: Qasim Nauman
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Olympic triathlon events were for set for Wednesday, a day after the men’s race was postponed over concerns about water quality in the Seine.

item.title: Their Parents Fled War. Now South Sudan’s Young Team Is in the Olympics.
item.description: War, famine and floods have beleaguered the world’s youngest nation. The arrival of its men’s basketball team at the Paris Olympics is set to offer a modicum of hope.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Guillem Sartorio for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Bright Stars are currently representing Africa in the Olympic men’s basketball tournament.

item.title: Not Even Anthony Edwards Can Beat an Olympic Table Tennis Player
item.description: An N.B.A. star’s trash talk was good-natured but typical, elite players said. They say they play along with it … to a point.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Keh and Chang W. Lee
item.media:description: Amy Wang of United States during a match on Monday.

item.title: At 17, She’s Already Conquered Some of the World’s Big Swims
item.description: While attention has been on the Paris Olympics, Maya Merhige, a high school senior, swam from England to France, completing the triple crown in open-water swimming.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Sophie Green for The New York Times
item.media:description: The 17-year-old swimmer Maya Merhige on the banks of the River Thames in London this month.

item.title: Israel Struck Beirut as ‘Axis of Resistance’ Leaders Attended Iran Inauguration
item.description: Iranian officials condemned the attack and warned that Hezbollah and Lebanon had the right to retaliate against Israel.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iran’s new president Masoud Pezeshkian was sworn in on Tuesday in an inauguration ceremony in Tehran.

item.title: Antidoping Agency Acknowledges Concern Over Use of Tainted Food as Excuse
item.description: After a spate of positive tests for performance-enhancing drugs by athletes, the World Anti-Doping Agency is investigating why China and other countries are citing contaminated food as an explanation.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Schmidt, Jenny Vrentas and Tariq Panja
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Joel Marklund
item.media:description: Witold Banka, the president of the World Anti-Doping Agency. The disclosures came at a time when the agency and the entire global antidoping system are under intensifying scrutiny.

item.title: After Dramatic Surrender, Son of El Chapo Pleads Not Guilty to Drug Charges
item.description: Joaquín Guzmán López gave himself up to U.S. authorities last week along with a former associate of his father’s.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Robert Chiarito
item.media:credit: Jose Luis Gonzalez/Reuters
item.media:description: The plane believed to have carried Ismael Zambada García and Joaquín Guzmán López to El Paso last week.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: Israel Targets a Hezbollah Commander
item.description: Plus, deadly street clashes in Venezuela and the Booker Prize longlist
item.dc:creator: Whet Moser
item.media:credit: Mohamed Azakir/Reuters
item.media:description: The site of an explosion in Beirut’s southern suburbs.

item.title: How Authoritarian Governments Rig Elections to Stay in Power
item.description: Nicolás Maduro was declared the winner of Venezuela’s presidential election despite widespread irregularities. Here are some tools autocrats like Mr. Maduro use to stay in power.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of a militia loyal to President Nicolás Maduro’s government at the entrance of a voting center in a neighborhood where the opposition lacked observers in Venezuela’s capital, Caracas.

item.title: Who Is Fuad Shukr, Target of the Israeli Strike on Beirut?
item.description: He is also wanted for his role in a 1983 attack in Beirut that killed some 300 American and French soldiers.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Ronen Bergman and Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Rewards for Justice, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photo of Fuad Shukr, from a wanted poster released by the U.S. State Department.

item.title: How the U.S. Reclaimed Its Golden Crown in Women’s Gymnastics Final
item.description: The United States pulled away, winning ahead of Italy, which won its first team medal since 1928, and Brazil, which claimed its first team medal ever.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor, Chang W. Lee, Gabriela Bhaskar and James Hill
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times

item.title: Here’s the latest on the attack in Beirut.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Adam Rasgon, Euan Ward and Hwaida Saad

item.title: Israel’s Military Has Shrunk Gaza’s Humanitarian Zone by a Fifth
item.description: Israel’s military has redrawn the zone’s borders twice, accusing Hamas of using it to regroup and launch missiles.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek and Lauren Leatherby
item.media:credit: Mohammed Salem/Reuters
item.media:description: Palestinians returned to the eastern side of Khan Younis in Gaza on Tuesday after Israeli forces pulled out of the area.

item.title: Hong Kong Taunts Italy With Pineapple Pizza After Olympics Fencing Win
item.description: After a fencer from Hong Kong beat an Italian for a gold medal, Pizza Hut’s offer of free pineapple toppings in Hong Kong was the city’s second jab at Italy.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Maye-E Wong/Reuters
item.media:description: Cheung Ka Long of Hong Kong celebrated after winning the gold medal bout against Filippo Macchi of Italy, in Paris on Monday.

item.title: Why Is China Pressuring the Philippines in the South China Sea?
item.description: China claims most of the strategic waterway and is trying to push out neighbors like the Philippines. Any deadly mistake could risk war.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chinese militia and Coast Guard vessels chasing a Philippine Coast Guard ship in the South China Sea last year.

item.title: Who Are the Druse in the Israeli-Controlled Golan Heights?
item.description: There are more than one million Druse, a religious group with roots in the 11th century, across the Middle East. There are about 150,000 Druse in northern Israel and the Golan Heights.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Druse residents gathering at the site of a rocket strike in Majdal Shams in the Israeli-controlled Golan Heights. There are more than a million Druse across the Middle East, mostly in Syria and Lebanon.

item.title: For Many Palestinians, the Olympics Are Easy to Root for but Hard to Actually Watch
item.description: The eight Palestinian athletes at the Games represent not only a homeland but a cause. But for those in Gaza, a scarcity of electricity has made it nearly impossible to keep up with the outside world.
item.dc:creator: Rawan Sheikh Ahmad
item.media:credit: Yves Herman/Reuters
item.media:description: Palestinian athletes taking a selfie on Thursday after arriving in Paris for the Olympics.

item.title: U.S. Pledges $500 Million in New Military Aid to the Philippines, as China Asserts Sea Claims
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III warned Beijing against engaging in hostilities with U.S. allies in the South and East China Seas.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Jam Sta Rosa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III with their Philippine counterparts at Camp Aguinaldo, the headquarters of the Philippine military, on Tuesday.

item.title: Energy Companies Turn to Robots to Install Solar Panels
item.description: Energy companies say a labor shortage is one big obstacle to installing more solar power. They’re turning to machines to speed things up.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer

item.title: You Won’t See Them at the Olympics, but These Speed Puzzlers Are World-Class
item.description: Puzzling has been around for more than 250 years, but a budding tournament featuring participants from more than 75 countries in Spain is giving it new life.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Hannah Cauhépé for The New York Times

item.title: Olympic Men’s Triathlon Postponed Because of Pollution in the Seine
item.description: Water-quality tests early Tuesday showed that the river running through Paris was unsafe for swimming, organizers said.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Seine was deemed unsafe to swim in early Tuesday.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: President Biden’s call to change the Supreme Court.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden wants term limits and an enforceable code of ethics imposed on the Supreme Court.

item.title: In the 1,500, There’s Katie Ledecky and Then There’s Everyone Else
item.description: Ledecky has not lost a 1,500-meter freestyle race in 14 years. Even her rivals admit they hit the water knowing they’re racing for second.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Vrentas
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: Katie Ledecky in her customary spot in the 1,500-meter freestyle: out front, and all alone.

item.title: China Cleared Swimmers in Doping Dispute, Citing Tainted Burgers
item.description: Two Chinese athletes, one of whom was named to the Olympic team in Paris, tested positive in 2022 for a banned steroid. China blamed contaminated food, as it had after previous positive tests.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja and Michael S. Schmidt
item.media:credit: Petr David Josek/Associated Press
item.media:description: Tang Muhan is a member of China’s Olympic team in Paris.

item.title: Netanyahu Vows ‘Severe’ Response to Deadly Rocket Attack Tied to Hezbollah
item.description: Fears linger among Lebanese civilians after a strike killed 12 children and teenagers in the Israeli-controlled Golan Heights.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner and Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Burned bicycles and scooters at the site of a rocket strike near the soccer field in the Druze town of Majdal Shams in the Israeli-controlled Golan Heights on Sunday.

item.title: El Chapo’s Son Abducted El Mayo and Flew Him to U.S., Officials Now Say
item.description: U.S. officials say Joaquín Guzmán López, a son of El Chapo, forced Ismael Zambada García onto a plane bound for the United States, in a case that landed the two Sinaloa cartel leaders in custody last week.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:credit: Alfredo Estrella/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico at a news conference following the arrest of Ismael Zambada García. Mr. Zambada García’s lawyer has said his client was kidnapped by Joaquín Guzmán López, El Chapo’s son.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Less Than 100 Days to Go
item.description: Plus, results in Venezuela’s tainted election and the new math of swimming.
item.dc:creator: Whet Moser
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Kamala Harris said that she would select a running mate by Aug. 7.

item.title: Is the Seine Clean Enough? Olympic Triathletes Wait on Testers.
item.description: Water-quality results recorded before dawn on Tuesday will determine if the men’s triathlon race will take place hours later.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A $1.53 billion project to clean up the Seine in time for the Olympics has come down to a last-second water-quality test.

item.title: Aides in Congress Create Dissent Channel to Protest Support for Israel
item.description: An anonymous group of junior staff members has modeled its effort on an internal State Department messaging system, hoping to create an outlet for calls for a cease-fire in the war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Maya C. Miller
item.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Protests near the Capitol last week while Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel spoke to a joint meeting of Congress. A group of staff aides organized a pro-Palestinian walkout on Capitol Hill the same day.

item.title: Protests Erupt in Venezuela After Contested Election Results Are Denounced
item.description: President Nicolás Maduro’s government ejected seven diplomatic missions from countries that condemned his claim of victory, which he made despite reports of fraud.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles, Jack Nicas and Alejandro Cegarra
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators protesting the outcome of the election on Monday in Caracas, Venezuela.

item.title: Huw Edwards, Former BBC Anchor, Charged With Making Indecent Images of Children
item.description: Huw Edwards, who led the BBC’s coverage of major events, including King Charles III’s coronation, has been charged with three offenses, the police said on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Chris Jackson
item.media:description: Huw Edwards speaking in London in 2020. Mr. Edwards, 62, presented the BBC’s flagship 10 o’clock evening newscast and led the broadcaster’s coverage of major national events.

item.title: Israeli Troops Held for Questioning in Prisoner Abuse Investigation
item.description: At least nine reservists were detained at a military base holding thousands of Gazans, prompting ultranationalists to break into the base in protest.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Johnatan Reiss and Gabby Sobelman
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: The entrance to the Sde Teiman base in the Negev desert, Israel, in May.

item.title: How a Crisis for Vultures Led to a Human Disaster: Half a Million Deaths
item.description: The birds were accidentally poisoned in India. New research on what happened next shows how wildlife collapse can be deadly for people.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.media:credit: Sanjay Baid/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A vulture in northern India, in 2020. A drug given to cattle in the 1990s nearly wiped out the birds in South Asia.

item.title: Ukraine’s Olha Kharlan Wins Bronze in Fencing at Olympics
item.description: The war has torn apart old alliances in fencing, and heightened the acrimony between Russia and Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman
item.media:credit: Yoan Valat/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Olha Kharlan of Ukraine celebrated after defeating Sebin Choi of Korea on Monday to win the bronze medal.

item.title: Southport Stabbing: 2 Children Killed and More Injured in Attack in U.K.
item.description: A 17-year-old was arrested after an assault that left two children dead and nine children and two adults injured. The police said it did not appear terrorism-related.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Adam Vaughan/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Police officers at the scene of stabbings in Southport, England, on Monday.

item.title: Olympics Opening Ceremony Singer Redefines What It Means to Be French
item.description: Aya Nakamura, the French Malian singer, did more than open the Games. She redefined what it means to be French.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Esa Alexander
item.media:description: Aya Nakamura, center, at the Olympics opening ceremony in Paris on Friday. The choice for her to perform prompted fierce debates over identity and language.

item.title: Man Detained in France After Entering Rail Site Near Rouen
item.description: The man was picked up near Rouen days after arsonists damaged train signaling cables around the country, but he is not a suspect in that case, prosecutors say.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.category: SNCF (Societe Nationale des Chemins de fer Francais)
item.media:credit: Denis Charlet/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Railway employees and police officers inspecting the scene of a suspected attack last week on the high-speed rail network in Croiselles, northern France.

item.title: Sinead O’Connor Died of Pulmonary Disease and Asthma, Death Report Says
item.description: A death certificate filed last week revealed the natural causes behind the death last July of Ms. O’Connor, the Irish singer and activist.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Ellius Grace for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sinead O’Connor in 2021. In January, a coroner said that Ms. O’Connor had died of “natural causes” but did not provide details.

item.title: Erdogan Says Turkey Could Enter Israel to Help Palestinians
item.description: It was unclear whether the comments reflected any concrete plans, but they drew a strong response from Israel.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
item.media:credit: Andrew Harnik/Getty Images
item.media:description: It was unclear whether comments by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, referring to the possibility that his country could enter Israel, reflected concrete plans.

item.title: African National Congress Expels Former President Jacob Zuma
item.description: The African National Congress party severed ties with its former leader over his decision to become the leading voice of an opposition party in the last election, calling its platform “dangerous.”
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Michele Spatari/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Jacob Zuma, the former president of South Africa, campaigning ahead of the South African elections in May.

item.title: Is the Olympic Flame Real?
item.description: Two torches may have lit it to open the Paris Games, but that’s not a fire in the cauldron.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Keh
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times

item.title: Olympic Gymnast Suni Lee Overcame Stalkers, Kidney Disease and Doubt
item.description: Sunisa Lee, the all-around women’s champion at the Tokyo Olympics, overcame personal strife, family expectations and serious illness to get to Paris.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sunisa Lee was a quiet 18-year-old from a conservative Hmong community in Minnesota. Then she won a gold medal at the Tokyo Olympics.
